They Never Really Leave

In 2022, my roommate Kyle donated my deceased Maine Coon, Chairman Meow, to Goodwill in a box labeled "soft things." By the time I got to the store, someone had already bought the box. I never found him.

That particular flavor of loss â€” not just death, but disappearance â€” is what broke me open. Grief needs something to hold. Not ashes in a tin. Not a paw print in plaster. The actual creature who loved you, preserved with the dignity they earned by putting up with you for all those years.

Still With You exists because I refuse to believe that the best we can do for the ones who slept on our faces is a laser-engraved urn from a company called Peternity.

Love doesn't have to be rational to be real.

Materials & Methods

The Ethical Promise

Every preservation begins with respect. We use only materials that would not horrify you if we listed them at a dinner party.

  • Eco-friendly tanning solutions â€” no formaldehyde, no regrets
  • Hand-painted glass eyes sourced from a family workshop in Bavaria that has been making them since 1927
  • Custom-sculpted polyurethane forms â€” each one modeled from your pet's photographs, not pulled from a shelf of generic cats
  • Archival-quality materials rated for 75+ years, because you're going to want Mr. Whiskers at the nursing home too

The Emotional Process

Here is what nobody tells you about therapeutic pet preservation:

When you see them again â€” mounted in their favorite pose, fur brushed, eyes catching the light the way they used to at 3 AM when they wanted breakfast â€” you will cry. This is not a side effect. This is the point.

We schedule a private reveal. Just you, your companion, and as many tissues as the situation requires. There is no rush. There is tea. Some clients sit with them for an hour before they can speak. That is fine. We have nowhere else to be.

You will know the difference between a preserved pet and a living one. But your nervous system might not â€” and that moment of confusion, that half-second of "they're home," is what we do this for.

Â§ Clinical note: We cannot accept animals euthanized due to aggressive behavioral conditions or communicable zoonotic diseases. We'll explain why privately if needed. This is a kindness, not a rejection.

Mr. Snuggles Came Home

Dear Beatrice,

I want you to know what happened the morning after I brought him home. I came downstairs and for half a second â€” I swear to God, half a second â€” I thought he was alive. He was on the couch in his spot, the one with the permanent dent, and the morning light was on his fur, and my brain just... forgot.

Then I remembered. And I cried. But it was a different kind of crying than before. Before, I was crying because he was gone. This time, I was crying because I got to see him one more time in his spot, looking like he'd just been napping. That's not the same kind of sad.

My daughter thinks I'm unhinged. She might be right. But Mr. Snuggles is home, and the house doesn't feel empty anymore, and I don't care what anyone thinks about that.

â€” Ethel M., Savannah, GA

Captain Biscuit Â· Golden Retriever Â· 2011â€“2024

The Dog Who Never Stopped Smiling

Captain Biscuit's owner, Ray, described him as "a golden retriever who somehow had even more golden retriever energy than the average golden retriever." He wanted the Captain mid-stride, mouth open, tail at full mast â€” what Ray called "the grocery store parking lot sprint," which was apparently Biscuit's signature move every single time Ray came home from anywhere, including the mailbox.

We mounted him on a driftwood base with one paw slightly lifted, ears back in that wind-tunnel-of-joy position. The hardest part was the tongue â€” you cannot taxidermy a tongue, so we sculpted one from medical-grade silicone, hand-painted to match his particular shade of enthusiastic pink. Ray says it's perfect. Ray says Biscuit would have eaten the silicone tongue if he were alive, which is probably true.
